spec.input:
MTBF means "Mean Time Between Failures, which is time that System spends in continuous up time between one failure and the next failure. MTBF is a measure of System reliability via continuous operation and therefore the MTBF target should be set at the highest achievable number. Users will not be notified of failures or down time".
MTTR means "Mean Time To Recovery, which is time that System spends in unscheduled down time until recovery as a result of failure. MTTR is a measure of System reliability via service recovery and therefore the MTTR target should be set at the lowest achievable number".
AWS means "Amazon Web Services".
Anonymous is "a person who is not identified in the system (not logged in). He can actually have a User account in our System, but we can't tell it until he logs in". Anonymous is an actor.
PublicData is "a collection of web pages with public information about Thindeck".
RuntimeStatistics is "a graphical and textual information representing average server availability per day, average server response time per day, current number of running servers, current number of repositories, current number of applications, similar to https://status.github.com/".
:UC9.1 is implemented. UC9.1 where Anonymous (an anonymous) explores thindeck: 1. The anonymous reads PublicData (a data); 2. The anonymous reads RuntimeStatistics (a stats).
:UC1 is implemented. UC1 where User (a user) deploys Application (an app): 1. The user creates Repository (a repo); 2. The repo launches the app; 3. The user reads the repo; 4. The user updates the repo; 5. The user deletes the repo; 6. The user pays for the repo.
:UC2 is implemented. UC2 where Repository (a repo) launches Application (an app): 1. The repo creates Deployment (a deployment); 2. The deployment executes the app; 3. The repo deletes the deployment "every 5 minutes, if repository sources are updated".
UC2/1 when "several domain-s and/or port-s are equal within repo": 1. "Notify the user via email about this"; 2. Fail as "can't launch app with conflicts".
:UC2.3 is implemented. UC2.3 where Deployment (a deployment) executes Application (an app): 1. Cloud (a cloud) creates Server (a server); 2. The server creates Container (a container); 3. The container creates the app; 4. Visitor (a visitor) utilizes the app; 5. The server deletes the container; 6. The cloud deletes the server.
UC6 where User (a user) pays for Repository (a repo): 1. The repo updates the user "decreasing his balance, every hour according to invoices of containers of deployments of repository"; 2. PayPal (a paypal) updates the user "charging his credit card and adding funds to his balance"; 3. The repo updates the user "via email when his balance is below $5".
:UC10.1 is implemented. UC10.1 where Visitor (a visitor) utilizes Application (an app): 1. The visitor reads the app; 2. Fail as "low balance" when "user balance is below $5"; 3. The visitor creates Invoice (an invoice); 4. The visitor updates the invoice "adding utilized CPU and traffic usage to it".
User is "a person who uses or wants to use hosting and is identified by the system (logged in)". User is an actor. User includes: repo-s? as Repository!, URN as "a unique identifier of itself, for example urn:github:526301", authTokens as "a list of auth tokens to each auth provider the user connected to, e.g., Google, Facebook, etc.", balance as "amount of money available, can be stored as integer number of cents".
Repository is "a local copy of files and folders being pulled every 5 minutes from some remote source". Repository includes: name as "a unique name of the repo in user's account", coordinates as "URI with user/password where sources can be found", deployment-s? as Deployment!, dockerFile as "a configuration for building and starting Container-s", domain-s as "a unique name that identifies a website and may not exceed a total length of 253 ASCII characters in its textual representation", port-s as "a 16-bit number that identifies a network port for the establishment of host-to-host connectivity".
Deployment is "a deployed and working instance of Repository". Deployment includes: container-s as Container! "the number of containers should be modified in runtime according to the current CPU load of existing containers.".
Container is "a virtual operating system running user's applications build from Repository. Virtualization technology a) must be open source or free, so that we avoid license costs, b) must be mature product that is currently supported, c) must provide full file system and network isolation, d) must enable memory and CPU quotas". Container includes: server as Server, logs as "text logs available in runtime and as historical records", state as "one from the list: building, running", invoice-s? as Invoice!.
Server is "a physical (or virtual) machine provided on-demand by Cloud". Server includes: ip as "IP address, as in RFC 1918", state as "one from the list: starting, running, terminating", container-s? as Container!.
Cloud is "a provider of on-demand virtual or physical servers, for example AWS". Cloud includes: credentials as "access credentials, including login, password, etc.", server-s? as Server!.
Invoice is "an atomic track record of the usage of resources, during one calendar hour". Invoice includes: container as Container, hour as "a calendar hour, for example: 2014-05-02T18", cpuSeconds as "how many seconds our CPU spent working with the container during this hour. Can easily be over 3600, since we may have multiple CPU's working with the container", bytesIn as "an integer number of bytes came into the container", bytesOut as "an integer number of bytes came out of the container".
PayPal is "a payment processing system, at www.paypal.com". PayPal is an actor. PayPal includes: credentials as "secret data for payment authorization".
Application is "a custom sofware application packaged inside Repository and executed in a Container".
UC1/SEC must "uniquely identify users and enable their login and logout operations, through secure HTTPS protocol".
UC1/UX must "expose user interface in English only".
UC1/WD must "be designed in 'responsive' manner, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Responsive_web_design . Since all Thindeck site pages will look good on every device, we won't need a separate mobile version of the site".
UC1/STL must "require all user repositories to be 100% stateless. We should inform users that we will be constantly changing the number of running containers. We may terminate any container at any moment. This means that the software inside the container (repository) should NOT keep any data persistent. They should use other services for persistence, like Amazon DynamoDB, etc".
UC1/API must "expose all features, which are available through UI, through RESTful API".
UC1/FIN must "present total summary of consumed resources to the user in a table with these columns: Container (id), Inbound traffic (Gb), Outbound traffic (Gb), CPU time (min), Cost ($). Each table row corresponds to a container. Last row contains totals by all containers. The values in the table are usage stats by container within specified time interval".
UC2/PERF must "each physical server should be able to host 4 actively working containers inside it, altogether handling 3M hits and 200 Gb of traffic per month, or 100K and 6.6 Gb per day".
UC2/MTBF must "be 30 days".
UC2/LOG must "be kept for 180 days since creation. Log is deleted once the 180 day mark is reached".
UC2/AVAIL must "be provided on deployment of an updated repository by using the blue-green deployment approach to minimize administrative downtime to less than 10 seconds".
UC9.1/MTBF must "be 30 days".
UC10.1/MTBF must "be 30 days in case a container is not responding to an expected port".
UC10.1/MTBF must "be 30 days in case a container is responding to a visitor's request in more than 30 seconds".
UC10.1/MTBF must "be 30 days in case an application which worked correctly at another server returns an internal server error after deployment in the system".
Vision: """
Requirements providers are:
* Yegor Bugayenko
Key success factors are:
* High availability - much higher than anyone else can offer. * Low cost - lower than anyone. * Easy (re)deployment - a unique 'pull' deployment mechanism. * Simple control panel - one form and your site is ready in 5 minutes.".
""".

info.informal: Mean Time Between Failures, which is time that System spends in continuous up time between one failure and the next failure. MTBF is a measure of System reliability via continuous operation and therefore the MTBF target should be set at the highest achievable number. Users will not be notified of failures or down time

Mean Time To Recovery, which is time that System spends in unscheduled down time until recovery as a result of failure. MTTR is a measure of System reliability via service recovery and therefore the MTTR target should be set at the lowest achievable number
Amazon Web Services
a person who is not identified in the system (not logged in). He can actually have a User account in our System, but we can't tell it until he logs in

info.informal: a virtual operating system running user's applications build from Repository. Virtualization technology a) must be open source or free, so that we avoid license costs, b) must be mature product that is currently supported, c) must provide full file system and network isolation, d) must enable memory and CPU quotas
text logs available in runtime and as historical records
one from the list: building, running

info.informal: an atomic track record of the usage of resources, during one calendar hour
a calendar hour, for example: 2014-05-02T18
how many seconds our CPU spent working with the container during this hour. Can easily be over 3600, since we may have multiple CPU's working with the container
an integer number of bytes came into the container
an integer number of bytes came out of the container

info.informal: be 30 days

method.markdown:
The following table describes all technical details of Use Case `UC9.1`:
Property Details
ID UC9.1
Signature anonymous explores thindeck
Primary Anonymous
Actors anonymous as Anonymous; data as PublicData; stats as RuntimeStatistics
Success Flow 1. anonymous reads data
2. anonymous reads stats
NFRs MTBF must "be 30 days"
Actors taking participation in the Use Case have the following properties:
Actor Properties
Anonymous "a person who is not identified in the system (not logged in). He can actually have a User account in our System, but we can't tell it until he logs in"
PublicData "a collection of web pages with public information about Thindeck"
RuntimeStatistics "a graphical and textual information representing average server availability per day, average server response time per day, current number of running servers, current number of repositories, current number of applications, similar to https://status.github.com/"
method.html:
The following table describes all technical details of Use Case UC9.1:

Property Details
ID UC9.1
Signature anonymous explores thindeck
Primary Anonymous
Actors anonymous as Anonymous; data as PublicData; stats as RuntimeStatistics
Success Flow 1. anonymous reads data
2. anonymous reads stats
NFRs MTBF must "be 30 days"

Actors taking participation in the Use Case have the following properties:

Actor Properties
Anonymous "a person who is not identified in the system (not logged in). He can actually have a User account in our System, but we can't tell it until he logs in"
PublicData "a collection of web pages with public information about Thindeck"
RuntimeStatistics "a graphical and textual information representing average server availability per day, average server response time per day, current number of running servers, current number of repositories, current number of applications, similar to https://status.github.com/"

info.informal: uniquely identify users and enable their login and logout operations, through secure HTTPS protocol
expose user interface in English only

be designed in 'responsive' manner, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Responsive_web_design . Since all Thindeck site pages will look good on every device, we won't need a separate mobile version of the site

require all user repositories to be 100% stateless. We should inform users that we will be constantly changing the number of running containers. We may terminate any container at any moment. This means that the software inside the container (repository) should NOT keep any data persistent. They should use other services for persistence, like Amazon DynamoDB, etc
expose all features, which are available through UI, through RESTful API

present total summary of consumed resources to the user in a table with these columns: Container (id), Inbound traffic (Gb), Outbound traffic (Gb), CPU time (min), Cost ($). Each table row corresponds to a container. Last row contains totals by all containers. The values in the table are usage stats by container within specified time interval

method.markdown:
The following table describes all technical details of Use Case `UC1`:
Property Details
ID UC1
Signature user deploys app
Primary User
Actors user as User; app as Application; repo as Repository
Success Flow 1. user creates repo
2. repo launches app
3. user reads repo
4. user updates repo
5. user deletes repo
6. user pays for repo
NFRs SEC must "uniquely identify users and enable their login and logout operations, through secure HTTPS protocol"
UX must "expose user interface in English only"
WD must "be designed in 'responsive' manner, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Responsive_web_design . Since all Thindeck site pages will look good on every device, we won't need a separate mobile version of the site"
STL must "require all user repositories to be 100% stateless. We should inform users that we will be constantly changing the number of running containers. We may terminate any container at any moment. This means that the software inside the container (repository) should NOT keep any data persistent. They should use other services for persistence, like Amazon DynamoDB, etc"
API must "expose all features, which are available through UI, through RESTful API"
FIN must "present total summary of consumed resources to the user in a table with these columns: Container (id), Inbound traffic (Gb), Outbound traffic (Gb), CPU time (min), Cost ($). Each table row corresponds to a container. Last row contains totals by all containers. The values in the table are usage stats by container within specified time interval"
Actors taking participation in the Use Case have the following properties:
Actor Properties
User "a person who uses or wants to use hosting and is identified by the system (logged in)"
  • repo: Repository
  • URN: "a unique identifier of itself, for example urn:github:526301"
  • authTokens: "a list of auth tokens to each auth provider the user connected to, e.g., Google, Facebook, etc."
  • balance: "amount of money available, can be stored as integer number of cents"
Application "a custom sofware application packaged inside Repository and executed in a Container"
Repository "a local copy of files and folders being pulled every 5 minutes from some remote source"
  • name: "a unique name of the repo in user's account"
  • coordinates: "URI with user/password where sources can be found"
  • deployment: Deployment
  • dockerFile: "a configuration for building and starting Container-s"
  • domain: "a unique name that identifies a website and may not exceed a total length of 253 ASCII characters in its textual representation"
  • port: "a 16-bit number that identifies a network port for the establishment of host-to-host connectivity"

exception.when: several domain-s and/or port-s are equal within repo

step.signature: "Notify the user via email about this"

info.informal: can't launch app with conflicts
every 5 minutes, if repository sources are updated
each physical server should be able to host 4 actively working containers inside it, altogether handling 3M hits and 200 Gb of traffic per month, or 100K and 6.6 Gb per day
be 30 days
be kept for 180 days since creation. Log is deleted once the 180 day mark is reached
be provided on deployment of an updated repository by using the blue-green deployment approach to minimize administrative downtime to less than 10 seconds

method.markdown:
The following table describes all technical details of Use Case `UC2`:
Property Details
ID UC2
Signature repo launches app
Primary Repository
Actors repo as Repository; app as Application; deployment as Deployment
Success Flow 1. repo creates deployment
2. deployment executes app
3. repo deletes deployment
NFRs PERF must "each physical server should be able to host 4 actively working containers inside it, altogether handling 3M hits and 200 Gb of traffic per month, or 100K and 6.6 Gb per day"
MTBF must "be 30 days"
LOG must "be kept for 180 days since creation. Log is deleted once the 180 day mark is reached"
AVAIL must "be provided on deployment of an updated repository by using the blue-green deployment approach to minimize administrative downtime to less than 10 seconds"
Actors taking participation in the Use Case have the following properties:
Actor Properties
Repository "a local copy of files and folders being pulled every 5 minutes from some remote source"
  • name: "a unique name of the repo in user's account"
  • coordinates: "URI with user/password where sources can be found"
  • deployment: Deployment
  • dockerFile: "a configuration for building and starting Container-s"
  • domain: "a unique name that identifies a website and may not exceed a total length of 253 ASCII characters in its textual representation"
  • port: "a 16-bit number that identifies a network port for the establishment of host-to-host connectivity"
Application "a custom sofware application packaged inside Repository and executed in a Container"
Deployment "a deployed and working instance of Repository"
  • container: Container "the number of containers should be modified in runtime according to the current CPU load of existing containers."

method.markdown:
The following table describes all technical details of Use Case `UC2.3`:
Property Details
ID UC2.3
Signature deployment executes app
Primary Deployment
Actors deployment as Deployment; app as Application; cloud as Cloud; server as Server; container as Container; visitor as Visitor
Success Flow 1. cloud creates server
2. server creates container
3. container creates app
4. visitor utilizes app
5. server deletes container
6. cloud deletes server
Actors taking participation in the Use Case have the following properties:
Actor Properties
Deployment "a deployed and working instance of Repository"
  • container: Container "the number of containers should be modified in runtime according to the current CPU load of existing containers."
Application "a custom sofware application packaged inside Repository and executed in a Container"
Cloud "a provider of on-demand virtual or physical servers, for example AWS"
  • credentials: "access credentials, including login, password, etc."
  • server: Server
Server "a physical (or virtual) machine provided on-demand by Cloud"
  • ip: "IP address, as in RFC 1918"
  • state: "one from the list: starting, running, terminating"
  • container: Container
Container "a virtual operating system running user's applications build from Repository. Virtualization technology a) must be open source or free, so that we avoid license costs, b) must be mature product that is currently supported, c) must provide full file system and network isolation, d) must enable memory and CPU quotas"
  • server: Server
  • logs: "text logs available in runtime and as historical records"
  • state: "one from the list: building, running"
  • invoice: Invoice
Visitor

info.informal: decreasing his balance, every hour according to invoices of containers of deployments of repository
charging his credit card and adding funds to his balance
via email when his balance is below $5

method.markdown:
The following table describes all technical details of Use Case `UC6`:
Property Details
ID UC6
Signature user pays for repo
Primary User
Actors user as User; repo as Repository; paypal as PayPal
Success Flow 1. repo updates user
2. paypal updates user
3. repo updates user
Actors taking participation in the Use Case have the following properties:
Actor Properties
User "a person who uses or wants to use hosting and is identified by the system (logged in)"
  • repo: Repository
  • URN: "a unique identifier of itself, for example urn:github:526301"
  • authTokens: "a list of auth tokens to each auth provider the user connected to, e.g., Google, Facebook, etc."
  • balance: "amount of money available, can be stored as integer number of cents"
Repository "a local copy of files and folders being pulled every 5 minutes from some remote source"
  • name: "a unique name of the repo in user's account"
  • coordinates: "URI with user/password where sources can be found"
  • deployment: Deployment
  • dockerFile: "a configuration for building and starting Container-s"
  • domain: "a unique name that identifies a website and may not exceed a total length of 253 ASCII characters in its textual representation"
  • port: "a 16-bit number that identifies a network port for the establishment of host-to-host connectivity"
PayPal "a payment processing system, at www.paypal.com"
  • credentials: "secret data for payment authorization"

info.informal: low balance
user balance is below $5
adding utilized CPU and traffic usage to it
be 30 days in case a container is not responding to an expected port
be 30 days in case a container is responding to a visitor's request in more than 30 seconds
be 30 days in case an application which worked correctly at another server returns an internal server error after deployment in the system

method.markdown:
The following table describes all technical details of Use Case `UC10.1`:
Property Details
ID UC10.1
Signature visitor utilizes app
Primary Visitor
Actors visitor as Visitor; app as Application; invoice as Invoice
Success Flow 1. visitor reads app
2. _self fail
3. visitor creates invoice
4. visitor updates invoice
NFRs MTBF must "be 30 days in case a container is not responding to an expected port" and "be 30 days in case a container is responding to a visitor's request in more than 30 seconds" and "be 30 days in case an application which worked correctly at another server returns an internal server error after deployment in the system"
Actors taking participation in the Use Case have the following properties:
Actor Properties
Visitor
Application "a custom sofware application packaged inside Repository and executed in a Container"
Invoice "an atomic track record of the usage of resources, during one calendar hour"
  • container: Container
  • hour: "a calendar hour, for example: 2014-05-02T18"
  • cpuSeconds: "how many seconds our CPU spent working with the container during this hour. Can easily be over 3600, since we may have multiple CPU's working with the container"
  • bytesIn: "an integer number of bytes came into the container"
  • bytesOut: "an integer number of bytes came out of the container"
method.html:
The following table describes all technical details of Use Case UC10.1:

Property Details
ID UC10.1
Signature visitor utilizes app
Primary Visitor
Actors visitor as Visitor; app as Application; invoice as Invoice
Success Flow 1. visitor reads app
2. _self fail
3. visitor creates invoice
4. visitor updates invoice
NFRs MTBF must "be 30 days in case a container is not responding to an expected port" and "be 30 days in case a container is responding to a visitor's request in more than 30 seconds" and "be 30 days in case an application which worked correctly at another server returns an internal server error after deployment in the system"

Actors taking participation in the Use Case have the following properties:

Actor Properties
Visitor
Application "a custom sofware application packaged inside Repository and executed in a Container"
Invoice "an atomic track record of the usage of resources, during one calendar hour"
  • container: Container
  • hour: "a calendar hour, for example: 2014-05-02T18"
  • cpuSeconds: "how many seconds our CPU spent working with the container during this hour. Can easily be over 3600, since we may have multiple CPU's working with the container"
  • bytesIn: "an integer number of bytes came into the container"
  • bytesOut: "an integer number of bytes came out of the container"

page.title: Vision

info.informal:
Requirements providers are:
* Yegor Bugayenko
Key success factors are:
* High availability - much higher than anyone else can offer. * Low cost - lower than anyone. * Easy (re)deployment - a unique 'pull' deployment mechanism. * Simple control panel - one form and your site is ready in 5 minutes.".

Requirements providers are:

Key success factors are:
